chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: In the following exercise, we need to explain the difference between the Net Present Value (NPV) index and the Profitability Index (PI).

First, let us start by recalling the definition of Net Present Value (NPV).

The NPV is an investment criterion that determines the difference between the present value of the future cash flows generated by the investment, and its cost.

The formula used to calculate the NPV is:

$$
\begin{align}
\text{NPV}= \sum_{i=1}^{t} \dfrac{\text{CF}_i}{(1+\text{r})^i} - \text{Initial Investment}
\end{align}
$$

Where:

$\text{CF}$: is the cash flow at the period $i$.

$r$: is the discount rate.

$t$: is the total number of periods.

Next, by substituting the expression for NPV from Equation 1 into Equation 2, we get:
$$
\begin{align}
\text{NPV}_\text I &= \dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^{t} \frac{\text{CF}_i}{(1+\text{r})^i} - \text{Initial Investment}}{\text{Initial investment}}\\[1.5em]
&= \dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^{t} \frac{\text{CF}_i}{(1+\text{r})^i}}{\text{Initial investment}} - 1
\end{align}
$$
Note that we have implicitly used the terms "cost" and "initial investment" interchangeably.

Finally, as for the relationship between both indices, let's compare their mathematical expressions.

Note that the first term on the right-hand side of Equation 4 corresponds to the expression for the Profitability Index obtained in Equation 5. Therefore, we can write:
$$
\begin{align*}
\text{NPV}_{\text{I}} = \text{PI} - 1
\end{align*}
$$
This last equation tells us that both indices are a measure of the benefit-to-cost ratio of an investment, and their values differ by one unit.

The profitability index and the net present value index are linked to each other and the profitability index is the ratio of benefits to cost, whereas the net present value index seems to be the ratio of net present value to cost, the net present value of a project is calculated by subtracting the cost of benefits.

Now, let's see the formula which captures the relationship between the net present value and the profitability index:

$$\begin{align*}
NPV&=PI-1
\end{align*}$$

where the net present value index is $NPV$ and the profitability index is $PI$

While subtracting one from the profitability index yields the net present value index. So the right side of the equation would become the ratio of the net present value to cost, and is similar to its net present value index, after subtracting.

Therefore, we can conclude that the net present value index is described as just a ratio of net present value to cost, then the net present value index, as well as the profitability index, would have the same relationship, with the net present value index matching the profitability index minus $1$.
